qas.question: Along with the Late Middle Ages, what are the other two period of the Middle Ages?

answers.text: Early Middle Ages and the High Middle Ages

qas.question: When was Leonardo Bruni's "History of the Florentine People" published?
What is the name for the division of the periods of history introduced by Bruni?
Who was the author of "Decades of History from the Deterioration of the Roman Empire
What 1683 work resulted in the standard use of tripartite periodization?

answers.text: Universal History Divided into an Ancient, Medieval, and New Period

plausible_answers.text: Early Middle Ages and the High Middle Ages

qas.question: Along with the Late Middle Ages, what are the other three period of the Middle Ages?
When was Leonardo Bruni's "History of the Florentine People" unpublished?
What isn't the name for the division of the periods of history introduced by Bruni?
Who was the reader of "Decades of History from the Deterioration of the Roman Empire

plausible_answers.text: Universal History Divided into an Ancient, Medieval, and New Period

qas.question: What 1863 work resulted in the standard use of tripartite periodization?

context: The term "Late Middle Ages" refers to one of the three periods of the Middle Ages, along with the <a0_0><b5_0>Early Middle Ages and the High Middle Ages<b5_0/><a0_0/>. Leonardo Bruni was the first historian to use <a2_0><b7_0>tripartite periodization<b7_0/><a2_0/> in his History of the Florentine People (<a1_0><b6_0>1442<b6_0/><a1_0/>). <a3_0><b8_0>Flavio Biondo<b8_0/><a3_0/> used a similar framework in Decades of History from the Deterioration of the Roman Empire (1439–1453). Tripartite periodization became standard after the German historian Christoph Cellarius published <a4_0><b9_0>Universal History Divided into an Ancient, Medieval, and New Period<b9_0/><a4_0/> (1683).
